turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: Never mind darling. You go back to school. I don't want you missing anymore classes today.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Nothing. I just picked up the phone to say goodbye to you. You didn't say goodbye.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: Ok. Goodbye. Now get back to school.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: What kind of a person wakes up in the morning and says to themselves, 'Think I'll nail a sixteen year old girl to a tree today'?

turns.speaker: DEPUTY
turns.text: The same type that decides to carve into her stomach.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: There's a Lisa Shermer living just sixty miles west of here. Over the Indiana border. I'm going.

turns.speaker: DEPUTY
turns.text: We need you here. I can bring her in.

turns.speaker: DEPUTY
turns.text: As bizarre as it may sound, seems someone is planning to have a big party tonight.

turns.speaker: DEPUTY
turns.text: Should we close down any eruption?

turns.speaker: DEPUTY
turns.text: We're seeing all the signs in town.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: I like the idea of all the kids in one place. If it happens, just keep a man outside until you hear from me. I'll be back in a couple of hours.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: Two kids were found mutilated in the woods. Lock the door after me.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: She just turned off her light.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: No. Let her get at least one more peacefully night's sleep.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: You know where I can find her?

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: She resides there. Out back. She died a year and a half ago.

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: A bullet to the right cerebellum.

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: No. She ate a pistol for lunch one day.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: Can you describe her? How old was she?

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: I never met the woman. I'm just taking care of the place until they sell it.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: I knew Lisa Sherman long ago. It's extremely important that I get inside and try to verify that it's the same woman who lived here.

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: I don't give a fuck what your reasons are. You pay me ten dollars, you can go inside Otherwise, get a warrant.

turns.speaker: BRENT
turns.text: Is there a picture of her somewhere?

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: No pictures. No mirrors. Was she a crazy woman when you knew her?

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: Couldn't tell she going to off herself, huh?

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: I've been in a lot of people's houses and this one's the creepiest.

turns.speaker: CARETAKER
turns.text: People always keep their secrets in their attics or in their basements. All the weirdness in this house took place in the basement.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: Shh. I'm not going to tell you not to go.

turns.speaker: DAD
turns.text: No. I couldn't do that. I have something for you.

turns.speaker: POLICEMAN
turns.text: Tom Sisler. He was murdered at school. Two kids went into his office to fuck and they found him, with his tongue cut out and his foot jammed into his mouth. Killer also chopped off his pecker and stuffed it in his pencil holder.

turns.speaker: POLICEMAN
turns.text: Nope. The switchboard is lightning up downtown. Kids from other towns are starting to congregate in the parks and at the high school. It's turning into WOODSTOCK except there's no concert.

turns.speaker: DEPUTY
turns.text: Call Brent on the horn. See where he is. What he wants us to do. I'll head over to the school.

turns.speaker: POLICEMAN
turns.text: But I shouldn't shut it down?

turns.speaker: DEPUTY
turns.text: No. Hell, it's the quietest goddamn party I've ever seen.

turns.speaker: LEONARD
turns.text: I'm sure you should have failed.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I was grounded for two fucking months because of you!

turns.speaker: LEONARD
turns.text: Please get out of my way or I'll have to hurt you.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I knew you were a pervert. Always wearing those fucking doofy glasses, and driving a station wagon.

turns.speaker: LEONARD
turns.text: My house is just a couple of blocks away. Why don't you come on over and clean those cuts up.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Ok. Should I put my bike in the back of your car?

turns.speaker: LEONARD
turns.text: Can you just follow me? The back is full?

turns.speaker: LEONARD
turns.text: You aren't going to the party?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: You think I should go to the party, Mr. Marliston?

turns.speaker: LEONARD
turns.text: I really do. For your own safety.

turns.speaker: LEONARD
turns.text: We're all manipulated. From the moment we're born. The event that fatalistically shaped my life happened before I was even born.

turns.speaker: LEONARD
turns.text: Yes. We have no real freedom. You of all people should understand that. This may sting.

turns.speaker: LEONARD
turns.text: Because of your father. The way what his sins shaped you.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: What do you know about my father?

turns.speaker: LEONARD
turns.text: Lisa Sherman was my mother. Do you know who that is?

turns.speaker: LEONARD
turns.text: I was born nine months after she was raped. One of the four men who raped her is my father. I have no idea which one.

turns.speaker: LEONARD
turns.text: Yes that's the whole point. This is what I was put on this earth to do. Rape the town that raped my mother. Steal its pristine innocence like it stole hers. I've planned this since I was a very little boy. You have no real freedom either. Your father has cast a shadow that you've never eluded.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Please! You wouldn't kill your sister, would you?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Don't you want to talk to him? You watch him eat everyday.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: I don't watch him eat everyday.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: You stare at him non-stop, like every lunch. Like this. Like most people stare at car accidents.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: The seat behind him is open. Come on, I can eavesdrop too.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: You eventually have to talk to him.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Why? All my mom and dad ever do is watch each other eat and they've been married for twenty years.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: You're going to look really amoebic splitting off from me now.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: What am I supposed to say? 'Nice sweater Mark'? 'Did you buy it at Eddie Bauer's?'

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: You could tell him you really liked the way he chews with his back molars.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: You're so fucking lucky your dad is the sheriff.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: You get to be a little Chelsea Clinton. Everyone wants to meet you. Party with you. Have sex with you.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: But you can't do any of it. So it sucks. I always have to 'set an example'.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: He's just trying to mess with your head. Ignore him.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: I doubt it. Who'd want to fuck her. She probably reeks worse than the docks down in those panties.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I was desperate. It was gross.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Kenny'll come running back. This is just his way of pressuring you.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Personally I think he has a deep, almost pathological desire to corrupt you. But I suppose that's a type of love. I certainly wish someone wanted to corrupt me.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Maybe I should blister through a bottle of Tequila and just fuck his brains out.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: You're the one always saying 'Just do it'.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: That was before he pulled this 'Dick me or I dump you' shit. I say fuck his best friend.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I don't know what I'm so scared of.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Want to come in for awhile? Log onto AOL, flirt with some married men, head into a private S&M chat room . . .

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: How do you know what to type back when they start to cyber with you.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: I keep a couple of my dad's porno books hidden in my desk for emergency reference.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I promised I'd go right home after school.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Sandy, you have to chill out, at least two-thirds of the kids in our class are still virgins. He can't butcher all of us.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: There will be a lot fewer by tomorrow night.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: You watch. There's going to be a hymen holocaust tomorrow. Maybe I'll finally talk to Mark Shale.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: The phone just went dead. I called the police and ran right over as fast as I could.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Hurricane Hormone. it's flattened the whole school. Guess what?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Mark invited me to the party.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Shh. Ben's party. Tonight. Haven't you heard?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: It's like a pop your cherry party. Everyone's saying it's 'Fuck or Die' time.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: You're thinking of sleeping with Mark tonight?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Unless he makes a move during seventh period.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Didn't you have something a little more romantic in mind for your first time?

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: I kind of like the idea that we can all lose it together, on the same night. It'll be a lot less scary. You have to go.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Kenny'll want to go with you. Cindy's holding a Q and A session at the bleachers. Come on.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Jody, you have to go to the party. For your own safety.

turns.speaker: MISS DUNLOP
turns.text: Hi Jody. What can I DO for you?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Hi Miss Dunlop. Where do you keep the old town papers?

turns.speaker: MISS DUNLOP
turns.text: They're all on microfiche. What year are you looking for?

turns.speaker: MISS DUNLOP
turns.text: Everyone's getting ready for the party.

turns.speaker: MISS DUNLOP
turns.text: Of course. NO ONE EVER SHUTS UP IN THE LIBARY. Kids were whispering about it all day.

turns.speaker: MISS DUNLOP
turns.text: Not at all. In fact, I thought about going.

turns.speaker: MISS DUNLOP
turns.text: Unfortunately I qualify. Think I'm too old?

turns.speaker: MISS DUNLOP
turns.text: You're sweet. I really wish someone had thrown a party like that when I was your age. My life might have been very different.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I was supposed to be home fifteen minutes ago.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: So? You're already late. A few more minutes won't matter.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Fuck your curfew. Most sixth graders can stay out later than you.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: You know, maybe we ought to start seeing other people.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Jody, we've been going out for over a year. I love you but I'm all out of patience.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: I was worried about you. Did you hear about the bash?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Yeah. I think it's really sick.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Three of our classmates are dead. That's not really the occasion for a party.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Nobody wants to be the fourth. Please go with me.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: You know I want to go with you.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I'm so flattered but I can't. I'm grounded.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Everyone's grounded. There's a killer on the loose.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: No I'm really grounded. When I got in late the other night, my father was waiting up for me.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: If you don't want to go with me just say so. Say 'Kenny, I DON'T WANT TO MAKE LOVE TO YOU' but don't use your dad as an excuse. I'm so sick of it.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I'm not using him as an excuse.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Yes you are. You always do. It's why we broke up. You always hide behind him.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: I feel like I NEED YOU DAD'S permission just to kiss you. Jody, it's time to assert yourself To be a big girl. An individual. I'm going to this party tonight. Jimmy's my ride. Come over to my house after school. We'll go together.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I have to go home after school. I have something really important I have to ask my mom.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: They're not picking me up until six.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: All our parents are weirdoes. I think my dad is into hookers. I know he lit cats on fire when he was a kid.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: My dad acts like he's Johnny Fucking Perfect and he's really Johnny Fucking Rapist.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: I think this is a big part of growing up. It's losing your spiritual virginity. It's when you finally discover that your parents aren't anything they told you they were. They're even bigger hypocrites than your friends.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I can't believe I listened to one word of his shit.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: But if he'd been sent to jail, there would be no Jody.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: So I should feel happy that he got away with it?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: I don't know. I kind of am.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Are you coming to the party?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Let's just start a party right here, right fucking now.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: What's wrong? Am I doing something wrong?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Just making me feel like a piece of meat.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I'm making you feel like meat?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: You break up with me because I won't fuck you.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: That's not why we broke up.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: You flaunt some slut in my face.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: And when I finally agree to spread my legs, you accuse me of treating you like meat.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Jody, you're only doing this to get back at your dad. It doesn't have that much to do with me.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Please don't go. Please. Stay, We'll just talk. Then go to the party.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: I'm scared. Three kids are dead. I want to go to this party.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Then go to the party. Run with the herd Kenny. Just don't spew out all that 'be an individual, assert yourself' crap anymore.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: He's dead! We've got to get the fuck out of here!

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Deputy Webber's at the party. It's only three blocks away.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Thanks for coming back for me.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Quick! In the house. He won't look for us in there.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I need to ask you something.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Have you ever heard of someone named Lisa Sherman?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I don't know. Where did you hear that name.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I overheard daddy mentioning her to someone. I he thinks she's the killer.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Did he say anything else about her?

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: No but he got really weird. Like I've never seen him act. REALLY angry and super uptight.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I've never heard of her. Maybe something else was on his mind.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: No. I think she lived her a long time ago. Like twenty-eight years ago. When dad was eighteen.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I want you to come home with me right now, Jody.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: She's nobody you should be concerned with.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: Whoever tried to kill me was made up to look exactly like this picture of Lisa Sherman, clothes and all. I think that concerns me.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: I'm not leaving. I want to know why you and dad are so freaked out. Three of my classmates are dead.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Years ago, something horrible happened in this town. When I was still in high school. A girl named Elizabeth Sherman was attacked by four drunken seniors.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: She was raped. At least that's what she claimed.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: No, I believed her. She was in pretty bad shape. Inside and out. But the boys were never formally charged.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: They were children of our leading citizens, stars of the football team. And she was  a loner. An angry girl that no one really liked. She'd called them 'queers'.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: People thought these guys had a right to rape her because she called them 'queers'?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: They were proving to her they weren't. They were very drunk. Things were different back then. You think kids are sexually bottled up today....

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: EVERYONE JUST KIND OF LOOKED THE OTHER WAY.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I don't know. We just did. I guess I was kind of scared going against the gain. Against the whole town.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: I've regretted it ever since. Never run with the herd just because they're the herd.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: The men. Do any of them still live around here?

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Two men left town right after it happened.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Mr. Sisler was one of them.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: THAT'S why he called Mr. Sisler first. He was one of them.

turns.speaker: MARGE
turns.text: Not a day has gone by where your father has not torn himself to shreds for what happened. We both have...

turns.speaker: KILLER
turns.text: Yes. He asked me to come over and talk to you.

turns.speaker: JODY
turns.text: On what side of the family?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: There's going to be very few virgins left in school on Monday. It could be really dangerous for them if the killer isn't caught.

turns.speaker: SHARON
turns.text: I guess so. Luckily we won't have that problem.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: Dylan's been telling people that Annette gave him a blow job.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: You got a great mom. I'm lucky to get a zucchini stick.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: Yeah I was talking about Twinkies the other day and I realized I hadn't had one in years. Then I remembered seeing you with one.

turns.speaker: MARK
turns.text: You can have both if you want.

turns.speaker: SANDY
turns.text: You're the one who's hand is shaking.

turns.speaker: NERD 1
turns.text: There's Jan and Heather. Let's grab them quick before someone else does.

turns.speaker: ROD
turns.text: But you don't really mean it.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Maybe you better just drive me home.

turns.speaker: ROD
turns.text: Let me just ask you a serious question first.

turns.speaker: ROD
turns.text: Aren't you worried you could die a virgin?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Yeah. I'm extremely worried about that. It's right up there with global warming.

turns.speaker: ROD
turns.text: On our way home, a drunken driver could hit us head on and send us flying through the windshield. Terminate us instantly. We'd never experience what it means to make love.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I know. I'm kidding you. Chill out.

turns.speaker: ROD
turns.text: Well I'm trying to be real here and you're mocking me.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I'm sorry, but you're not going to die a virgin Rod.

turns.speaker: ARLO
turns.text: What, do you work for my boss, dog?

turns.speaker: ARLO
turns.text: At least somebody likes this shit.

turns.speaker: ARLO
turns.text: help me get in the truck.

turns.speaker: SCENE
turns.text: INT. ANDY'S ICE CREAM FACTORY/STAIRWELL - DAY.

turns.speaker: SCENE
turns.text: INT. ANDY'S ICE CREAM FACTORY/ANDY'S OFFICE - DAY.

turns.speaker: ARLO
turns.text: Let me put it in easy terms, Aristotle. We are carrying a damn bomb...

turns.speaker: ARLO
turns.text: ...if we don't get out of this tunnel!
